nealrichardson commented on issue #6366: ARROW-1581: [Packaging] Tooling to make nightly wheels available for install
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/6366#issuecomment-585277779
 
 
   Wouldn't it be simpler to upload the wheels to ursalabs bintray instead of GitHub release artifacts? Then there's no HTML to generate, no webpages to host. Less (untested) code too, it's one `curl` per wheel.

pitrou commented on issue #6366: ARROW-1581: [Packaging] Tooling to make nightly wheels available for install
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/6366#issuecomment-585750794
 
 
   The following works:
   ```
   $ pip install numpy six  # fetch from PyPI
   $ pip install -v --index-url https://ursalabs.org/crossbow/pypi/ pyarrow
   ```
   
   The following fetches from PyPI, probably because "0.16.0" is a later version than "0.16.0.dev57":
   ```
   $ pip install -v --extra-index-url https://ursalabs.org/crossbow/pypi/ pyarrow
   ```
   
   ```python
   >>> from pkg_resources import parse_version
   >>> parse_version("0.16.0") > parse_version("0.16.0.dev57")
   True
   ```
   
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.

fields.summary: [Packaging] Tooling to make nightly wheels available for install

comments.body: Are you planning on putting these on PyPI? I'd like to do something similar with Ray, ideally people would be able to pip install the project from any commit. Sort of like https://pypi.python.org/pypi/tf-nightly except with every commit, not just the most recent.

I don't see why not to put them on PyPI as long as the Apache project does not advertise them. It might be a little work to munge the package metadata to do this. I have already found having the conda nightlies to be incredibly useful
[~wesmckinn] What would be the problems with package metadata here? {{setuptools_scm}} should take care of providing a continuous version number suitable for nightly builds.

After merging https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/2162 and setting this [branch|https://github.com/kszucs/crossbow/blob/master/.travis.yml#L45] to master the nightlies will be uploaded to github releases.

So I have to object a little bit to resolving this issue as there's no visibility into these builds. If someone wanted to start using them, how would they do that? I know that [~robertnishihara] [~pcmoritz] and others would make use of these for development
Reopening until we figure out the developer workflow for using the nightly builds, and document it on https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/ARROW
What is the desired user flow here? Listing nightly wheel artifacts on a web page? And having a latest link to download the most recent wheel?
